div1.p: This report is a detailed account of the yellow fever epidemic in French West Africa, including information on control measures, vaccinotherapy, serotherapy, and experimental findings.

div1.head: Report on the Epidemic of Yellow Fever at Grand-Bassam, by Bauvallet and Houillon, October 25, 1923
div1.opener:
Blanndt Grand Bassam No 1 & 2?
REPORT ON THE EPIDEMIC OF YELLOW FEVER
AT GRAND-BASSAM
(August 18 to September 8, 1922.)
****
French West Africa
Colony of the Ivory Coast
Health Service.
div1.p:
The information that brought to our attention a few cases
of yellow fever in Dahomey, Togo and the Gold Coast in July did
not find us unprepared.

In fact, as early as June 28, and before any official notifica-
tion, the Chief Physician, Head of the Health Service, came down to Bassam
to examine a patient who had been reported by the physician at that post.
This was the sailor A. of the S.S. “New Georgia”, coming from the south.
This man was found to be suffering from malaria, and the ship was declared
free from Stegomyia.

On July 29 some patients on board the “Barracoo”, also from
the south, engaged our attention. One of those patients, the ship-boy B.,
died on the 31st. The development of the disease, the anamnesis, and the post-
mortem findings all established the diagnosis of a pernicious attack of malaria.
This diagnosis was confirmed by the absence of contagion and of Stegomyia.
The ship remained anchored in the roads for 16 days and no one on board
fell ill.

A very strict and constant supervision of the native morbidity
and mortality gave only negative results.

The marine sanitary police supervision was carried out under
conditions of complete security, since it was physically impossible to
land except at the wharf. All arrivals by the sea from the south were
examined on arrival, and all passengers were observed for 6 days without any
abnormal findings.

However, danger did exist on the land side on account of
the proximity of the Gold-Coast. Bassam is one day's journey on foot
from Aferonou, the English frontier post. Continual and unsupervised
communication took place by way of the shore. This explains how an
Italian Mr. C., who left Accra by the road, was able to reach Bassam
on June 29, brought in by his men in a state of complete coma, without
having his passage of the frontier known to anyone. In this case it
was nothing but sunstroke with resulting mental confusion, which was
quickly cured.
The month of July passed with nothing of note.

Mrs. D. of the Atlantic Hotel died on August 4. The records
show that the symptoms were those of bilious hematuria. There was no
one infected in the vicinity of the patient. This case was brought to
the attention of the Chief of the Health Service on account of an epi-
gastralgic symptom. This symptom alone was not sufficient to allow us to
pronounce the word yellow fever, the diagnosis of which haunted us and
became almost obsession.

Seventeen days after the beginning of Mrs. D.'s fatal illness
a resident of the Atlantic Hotel, Mr. E., was admitted in haste to the
Ambulance Hospital at Bassam. He fell ill on August 16. On the 17th
he had a pathognomonic attack of black vomit, and died at 6:45 P.M. The autopsy, which was made on the forenoon of the 18th, revealed a
hemorrhagic stomach filled with “coffee grounds”, a chamois-colored
liver, and a saffron-yellow skin. The Chief of the Health Service, to
whom the case was reported by telegram under date of the 17th, came down
to Bassam on the 18th and confirmed the diagnosis by examination of the pieces.

Mr. E., who had no means of any kind, had managed to live in
Bassam for several months by various shifts, and led a mysterious kind of
existence.

He belonged to a group of Italians who had made their head-
quarters at the Atlantic Hotel. These Italians, who came from the Gold-
Coast to recruit laborers, sometimes vanished for a week at a time, and
E. did the same.

As these recruiting agents had found themselves refused permission
to carry on their activities, it is perfectly logical to suppose that the
high exchange value of the pound sterling made it possible for them to
engage men just the same. Thus E. and F., another Italian of the same group,
living under unsanitary conditions and especially without mosquito nets,
got infected at Accra, where yellow fever was officially recognized, when
they secretly took a group of laborers there.

The case of E. created an accidental center which developed
chronologically in the following way among the guests, the neighbors, and
the patrons of the Atlantic Hotel, a particularly ill-kept property the
cleaning-up of which is a sanitary necessity.

August 18, case G. The disease appeared during the night
of the 18th with coup de barre, facial congestion, epigastralgia, vomit.
The development was favorable, and the patient recovered.

4. August 20, case of Mrs. H. The patient fell ill about
August 15, and was treated at home, Fever, epigastralgia, vomiting,
then uterine hemorrhage, icterus, albuminuria followed by anuria. Died
on August 20. There was no autopsy, as the patient was cared for by her
family.

August 21, case I. This Syrian fell ill about 10 A.M. on
the 21st. Rachialgia, facial congestion, high fever, vomiting all
came on at once. The disease developed very rapidly. Died at 2 P.M.
on the 22d. There was no autopsy, partly for lack of time and partly
on account of the clear clinical indications.

All sick persons with a fever were examined and their cases
discussed by Physician-Major Bauvallet and Chief Physician Houillon, Head
of the Health Service.

As soon as the first case was reported the Bassam territory
was put under observation, and on the 20th of the month it was declared
infected with yellow fever.
CONTROL MEASURES PUT INTO EXECUTION.
A conference took place on August 18 about 9 A.M. between:

M. Houillon, Chief Physician of the 1st class of the T. C.,
Head of the Health Service of the Ivory Coast.
M. Mondon, Administrator and Mayor of Bassam.

M. Bauvallet, Physician-Major of the 2nd class of the T. C.,
physician of Bassam.

A plan of sanitary mobilization, the details and possibility
of which had been discussed long before by the Health Service, was decided
upon in its larger aspect. A meeting of the Committee on Hygiene, composed
of members of the Municipal Commission, was hastily called and informed of
the state of affairs.

The public was informed, in a circular that was composed at
once, of the existence of a death by yellow fever, of the precautionary
measures to be taken, and of the necessity of reporting every case of illness
accompanied by fever. Besides, a sanitary bulletin was established and
published daily to the population of Bassam during the whole epidemic,
according the the formally expressed wish of the Head of the Health Service
and the resulting decision of the administrative authorities, who thought
it absolutely necessary that the inhabitants be exactly informed and warned
against false reports.

The following control measures, the rapid execution of which
was one of the chief factors of success, considering that there was no
European quarantine station in Bassam, were carried out.

1. Requisition of all mosquito netting, which was put at the
disposal of the entire population on the indication of the medical author-
ities, in order to protect everyone.

2. Installation of mosquito traps in every suspected or infected
house.
(No point 3 in original)

4. Disinfection, by hot cresyl fumes, of every house that was
infected or harbored Stegomyia.

5. Isolation of every one suspected of infection (persons
in the vicinity of the sick) either in their homes or in hastily prepared
buildings. The Richmond house was requisitioned, with 5 beds; two rooms in
the European Ambulance Hospital, 10 beds; first floor of the Maternity
Hospital, 10 beds.

6. Isolation of all fever patients before diagnosis, under
mosquito nets, and with mosquito traps at the doors. Isolation and ob-
servation, under (proper) conditions, of 9 Europeans, all of them uninfected.

7. Checking up, repairing and distributing mosquito nets to
well persons.

8. Increase in the severity of Stegomyia control. This control
had been begun in Bassam several years before, but had become much more
effective since June, particularly on account of the large increase
in legal summons followed by judgments. The relative scarcity of
Stegomyia in Bassam, due to the activity of the Health Service, and
pointed out by Dr. Bauvallet and Dr. Blanchard, explains why the
early cases, which were the only ones that appeared, were limited to
5. The Health Service functioned as usual with the regular personnel
during the epidemic, in addition to a few workmen loaned by the
Administrator-Mayor. The search for the hiding places of Stegomyia
larvae was carried on by the regular specialized brigades in the six
control sectors established since August, 1920, 2 of these being European
and the other 4 native. It must however be noted that the entire house
to house visits were made under the direction either of a sworn European
agent of the Health Service or of a physician. Valuable, efficient and
disinterested assistance was spontaneously given by M. Landre, a planter
of the Ivory Coast, who was passing through Bassam, and who came to offer
his services to the physician in charge.

9. Visiting, disinfecting, clearing of mosquitoes and oiling
of the coastal steamers and barges that were blocked at Bassam by the
quarantine. This service was under the direction of Sergeant Javelas,
of Batallion No. 3, who was placed at the service of the Bassam physician
by the military authorities.

10. Order of service, guards composed of sharpshooters of
Batallion No. 3, loaned by the Batallion Chief Steef, military commander,
at the request of the physician of Bassam, and placed in every infected
or suspected house. These soldiers were under the direct command of the
Physician, who gave them a very simple order, which consisted of keeping
absolutely everyone out of the houses under observation.

11. Printed information, got out and distributed at the
suggestion of the Head of the Health Service, gave the public excellent
advice. Samples of Stegomyia in tubes were circulated by the physician
of Bassam.

12. Talks were given by M. Mondon to the native chiefs
of the Circle. Every case of illness, and all deaths, which were
very few, were inspected by the physician, thanks to the reports of
the village chiefs. No native, either before, during, or after the
epidemic, presented any morbid symptoms that could lead one to suspect
yellow fever.

13. Placing under observation, individual mosquito nets, in
the quarantine station, of every native coming from the Gold Coast, either
by land or water.

14. All Europeans who landed at Bassam during the course of
the epidemic were given “sanitary passports”, and were sent away im-
mediately by day in automobiles.

15. The organization of a sanitary cordon around the infected
zone.

16. Sanitary observation of the population living on the
frontier of the Gold Coast. Nothing suspicious found in the Aboisse
section.

The successful conception, execution and control of all these
measures, the practical application of which bristled with difficulties,
were due to the close collaboration of the Head of the Health Service,
the Administration, the Bassam Physician, and the Hygienic Commission.

As a whole the population of Bassam good-naturedly accepted
all the required restrictions, even those that were very unpleasant,
such as house inspections. It would have been fatal, and it did happen
in a few cases, that ill-natured persons complained of despotism and
denied the presence of yellow fever. When necessary, regular penal
action was most successfully applied.

The physician stationed in Bassam, which is a city particularly
exposed to epidemics, had already entered into personal correspondence
with Mr. Hideyo Noguchi of the Rockefeller Institute in 1921, and had
received from him early in 1922 a certain amount of anti-yellow-fever
serum and vaccine preserved in ice.

At the very beginning of the epidemic a circular letter was
published informing the inhabitants that anyone who wished it would be
vaccinated in accord with the results published by the eminent Japanese
biologist.

From August 18 to 24, 140 Europeans out of a population of about
200 were vaccinated with dead cultures of Leptospira icteroides from lot 15,
prepared on December 9, 1921. One hundred and thirty-one received two
injections of 2 cc. at an interval of 6 days, according to the author's
technique; 9 did not appear for the second injection.

Practically all of the persons vaccinated presented the following
reaction on the evening of the day on which they had received the injection
between 8 and 10 A.M.; light fever with pain in the small of the back, more
or less marked rachialgia, typical picture of the “coup de barre”, consisting
of very severe pain in the lumbar region. The intensity of the rachialgia
was what kept 8 of the 9 that had the first injection only from returning
for the second. The ninth of these persons is mentioned in a special report
at the end of this one.

Four of the persons vaccinated presented sterile abscesses, indicated
by Noguchi as being due to the presence of agar-agar in the culture medium,
after 15-20 days and appearing at the point of innoculation in spite of
systematic massage immediately after the penetration of the skin by
the vaccine. These abscesses were cured by simple cupping and left
no scars.

At the same time serotherapy with Noguchi's serum, kept
at a temperature of minus 4 degrees Centigrade, was applied to all
the patients, in addition to the classical and purely symptomatic
treatment.
The results of this serotherapy were as follows:

Case 1.- The diagnosis of yellow fever was not absolute
until the appearance of the black vomit. The patient received immediately,
at 4:30 P.M., an intravenous injection of 60 cc. of serum. Death occurred
at 5:43 P.M. This injection was given in extromis, after the third day,
when it is said by Noguchi to be no longer of any value.

Case 2.- The disease made its appearance in the evening
of August 18, with a very high fever. The patient said that he had
had a temperature of 39.9 degrees C. at the time. The case was not
reported until the next morning, when the patient was isolated in the
Ambulance hospital. Pain in the back, “coup de barre”, congestion of
the face, epigastralgia, scant urine with no albumen. Temperature of
39.4. Received 60 cc. of serum at 8:30 A.M. Decrease in temperature
and diuresis in the afternoon; cure.

Case 3.- High fever during the night of the 17-18. Seen by the
physician on the 18th at 9 A.M. Temperature of 39.2, extreme pain in the
lumbar region, cramps in the legs, bilious vomit and internal epigastralgia,
albuminuria. Received 60 cc. of serum intravenously. The temperature
fell to 38.6 in the afternoon. Decrease in the vomiting, appearance of a
subicteric condition that persisted until August 24. Disappearance of the
albuminuria; defervescence; cure.

Case 4.- Patient fell ill on August 15, but her husband did
not call a physician, as he thought that it was merely a fever due to
acclimatization. Isolated only in the evening of the 17th, actually later
than case 1., although the symptoms suggested a malarial attack. On the
19th the diagnosis became evident; slight uterine hemorrhages, epigastralgia,
bilious vomit, congestion of the face, prostration, subicterus, scant
urine with albumen. Was given as intravenous injection of 60 cc. of serum.
On the 20th the icterus was general and the prostration still more marked;
there were subcutaneous sanguineous effusions and the anuria was total.
A second intravenous injection of 60 cc. of serum was administered; a few
drops of very albuminous urine were expelled after the injection. Death
at 7.10 P.M. The serotherapeutic treatment was late and useless.

Case 5.- The patient took to bed on the 21st about 10 A.M.
Was seen at once and sent to the Ambulance hospital to be isolated.
No pain in the lumbar region, but epigastralgia, bilious vomit, congestion
of the face. The temperature remained at from 39.2 to 39.6 during the
whole day of the 21st. The patient passed a restless night, with a tem-
perature of 39.8 at 7 A.M. on the 22nd. Received 60 cc. of serum less than
4 hours after the beginning of the disease. The vomiting continued and was
tinged with blood. Death at 1:45 P.M. The treatment was not totally un-
successful; autopsy was not performed on account of lack of time.

One case must receive special mention, that of the ninth person
who had only one injection.

Mr. B..., living at the Atlantic Hotel, and a neighbor of Mr. X...,
and Mr. Y..., received 2 cc. of vaccine on August 22, but did not appear for
the second injection on the 23rd. The proprietor of the Atlantic Hotel,
on being asked over the telephone as to why Mr. B... remained absent,
replied guardedly that Mr. B... was not well. The patient was seen at
10:30 A.M. He had had no reaction after the first injection, but on the
night of the 27-28 he had a fever and a back-ache. He did not take his
temperature at the time. When seen his temperature was 39.2. “coup de barre”,
cramps in the legs, congestion of the face that was in marked contrast to
his usual pallor, gums edged with white, a symptom that appeared only in
this case, vomiting, albuminuria. Was isolated in the Ambulance hospital,
and received an intravenous injection of 60 cc. of serum at 1 P.M.
The patient immediately presented an intense seric reaction, pruritus,
generalized erythrosis, very grave syncope. An intravenous injection
of 1 mg. of adrenaline caused the disappearance of the anaphylactic
phenomena. The fever and the disturbing symptoms disappeared during the
night.
EXPERIMENTAL FINDINGS.

It is perfectly clear that the great number and urgency of
the activities to be carried on did not allow the physician of Bassam,
who is alone at this post, to make any consecutive microbiological exam-
inations, especially early in the epidemic, when everything had to be done
at once.

It was however possible to obtain the following findings in the
case of Mr.

Three cc. of blood was collected from the patient's vein with
a citrated seringe before the injection of serum.

This citrated blood was immediately injected into the
cellular tissue of the shaved and disinfected abdominal wall of guinea pig
No. 1.

This guinea pig was isolated under a mosquito net and died during
the night of September 4-5, 7 days after innoculation. The animal's temper-
ature curve showed a distinct hypothermia, 39.4 degrees, in the evening of
the 4th. The autopsy was made the next morning. The animal was very thin,
with no icterus of the skin or conjunctiva; but there was subicterus of
the muscles. Intense congestion of the lungs and kidneys, with small
hemorrhagic foci. The bladder contained 1 cc. of very albuminous urine.
The stomach contained food and revealed a mucous membrane with hemorrhagic
spots in the vicinity of the pylorus. The intestinal mucous membrane had
the same appearance at the level of the duodenum. The liver was very con-
gested but showed no degeneration.

Sections of the liver and the kidney were aseptically removed
and placed in the oven at 32 degrees in Ringers solution. Smears of the
centrifuged cultures and fragments of the viscera preserved in formol
have been sent to the Rockefeller Institute.

The examination made in Bassam under poor conditions, the
ultra-microscope being badly lighted on account of the lack of a light
condenser, did not reveal the presence of Leptospira icteroides.

Since the end of this epidemic no cases of yellow fever, or
resembling yellow fever, has been found in Bassam, either among the
natives or the Europeans.

There is therefore no question of the revival of an endemicity
the continuity of which would have been preserved by the natives.

It is at present possible to affirm that the importation
of an original case of yellow fever, probably from the Gold Coast,
created a small accidental epidemic focus that was quickly extinguished.
Grand-Bassam, October 25, 1923.
Physician-major

(Signed) Dr. Bauvallet, of the 2nd class, physician of the post of Bassam.
Dr. Houillon, Chief Physician of the 1st class of the T.C.,
Head of the Health Service of the Ivory Coast.
